repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body: Is end row really exclusive?, or is it just end col and end byte
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,23 +2,23 @@ local api = vim.api
 
 local M = {}
 
----@class Range2
----@field [1] integer start row
----@field [2] integer end row
-
----@class Range4
----@field [1] integer start row
----@field [2] integer start column
----@field [3] integer end row
----@field [4] integer end column
-
----@class Range6
----@field [1] integer start row
----@field [2] integer start column
----@field [3] integer start bytes
----@field [4] integer end row
----@field [5] integer end column
----@field [6] integer end bytes
+---@class Range2 Range represented by rows
+---@field [1] integer start row (0-indexed).
+---@field [2] integer end row (0-indexed, exclusive).

comment_data.body:
I think the relevant usage is
```
    local tree = parser:parse({ start_row, end_row })
```
which parses the line `[start_row, end_row)`.

Also there is a trivial and natural upcasting from Range2 to Range4 (see `vim.treesitter._range.unpack4`):
```
(3, 7) => (3, 0, 7, 0)
```
and both represent the *exactly* the same region. `(3, 0, 7, 0)` might be equivalent to `(3, 0, 6, 80)` assuming the number of columns is 80 in line 6 (0-indexed).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,23 +2,23 @@ local api = vim.api
 
 local M = {}
 
----@class Range2
----@field [1] integer start row
----@field [2] integer end row
-
----@class Range4
----@field [1] integer start row
----@field [2] integer start column
----@field [3] integer end row
----@field [4] integer end column
-
----@class Range6
----@field [1] integer start row
----@field [2] integer start column
----@field [3] integer start bytes
----@field [4] integer end row
----@field [5] integer end column
----@field [6] integer end bytes
+---@class Range2 Range represented by rows
+---@field [1] integer start row (0-indexed).
+---@field [2] integer end row (0-indexed, exclusive).

@@ -155,12 +157,13 @@ TSNode:tree()                                           *TSNode:tree()*
                                                 *TSNode:descendant_for_range()*
 TSNode:descendant_for_range({start_row}, {start_col}, {end_row}, {end_col})
     Get the smallest node within this node that spans the given range of (row,
-    column) positions
+    column) positions. The range follows the convention of |TSNode:range()|.

@@ -155,12 +157,13 @@ TSNode:tree()                                           *TSNode:tree()*
                                                 *TSNode:descendant_for_range()*
 TSNode:descendant_for_range({start_row}, {start_col}, {end_row}, {end_col})
     Get the smallest node within this node that spans the given range of (row,
-    column) positions
+    column) positions. The range follows the convention of |TSNode:range()|.

comment_data.body: Then, these lines are also wrong (see #26569)? Or, we are just abusing 0-length ranges?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -391,6 +396,7 @@ function M.get_node(opts)
 
   assert(row >= 0 and col >= 0, 'Invalid position: row and col must be non-negative')
 
+  ---@type Range4
   local ts_range = { row, col, row, col }

comment_data.body: here too. (there could be more, not shown in this diff)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -417,6 +423,8 @@ function M.get_node_at_pos(bufnr, row, col, opts)
   if bufnr == 0 then
     bufnr = api.nvim_get_current_buf()
   end
+
+  ---@type Range4
   local ts_range = { row, col, row, col }

comment_data.body: Yes this is wrong. Needs to be `col + 1`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -391,6 +396,7 @@ function M.get_node(opts)
 
   assert(row >= 0 and col >= 0, 'Invalid position: row and col must be non-negative')
 
+  ---@type Range4
   local ts_range = { row, col, row, col }

comment_data.body: I see, thanks for confirming. Will fix this in another follow-up PR.

title: docs(treesitter): explicitly mention ranges are 0-indexed, end-exclusive
